sourceDesc.bibl: Chicago Foreign Language Press Survey, 1936-1941, Works Projects Administration, Chicago Public Library Omnibus Project

revisionDesc.change: Initial TEI transcription from PanGeo Partners, Inc.

body.p: Artists who are not preceded by their fame, gerecrally find in a difficult position toward the public. They first Mastery of instruments is not any longer rare today, and the public must be convinced that the artist is a master it is willing to hear him.

It is not surprising under surprising those circumstarces, that the concert last right in the now Chicago theater, by the Russian pianist, Mme. Annette Bssipoff, did not draw a large crowd, but there were a great number of teachers in the audience.

. Annette is an excellent and in certainly not inferior to Alice Topp or Anna Heslig. She played to perfaction the Andante and the Impromptu from: "Rose wade" by schubert, as well as Schumanns's " and "Les doux Alouettes", a composition by , Director of the St. Petersburg Conservatory of Music.

The public awaited with special interest her interprotation of Chapin. Her requtation to be the best interpreter of this composer does not seem to us to be justified. Her playing lacks the necessary power to render the stormy ideas of Chopin.
Mrs. lived up to the expectations of her audience. The only thing lacking seemed to be power, and this was perhaps due to the almost empty hall.
